[#image: /photos/53d9ba496dec627b149cc933]||||||

[#image: /photos/53d9ba496dec627b149cc915]|||Skip the Giza crowds and take in the sights at the Saqqara Pyramids|||

[#image: /photos/53d9ba496dec627b149cc913]||||||




## _Condé Nast Traveler_ Senior Correspondent SUSAN HACK shares her favorite meals in Cairo

## 
1. **AL GAHSH** Cairo’s beloved all-day breakfast outpost serves just two things: _fuul_, a filling mash of stewed, spiced fava beans spooned into whole-wheat pita with fried eggs, arugula, and pickles; and _tamiya_, beans mashed with coriander, rolled into patties, and deep-fried. The founder’s friendly extended family speak a little English, and the place stays open until 4 a.m. You can get sandwiches wrapped to go, or feast at tables on the rooftop balcony (Maraseena St. near the Sayyida Zeinab mosque; no phone).







## 
        1. **[ABOU TAREK](http://aboutarek.com)** _Koshary_—a heaping bowl of rice and short noodles, served with lentils stewed in cumin and garlic and topped with a cinnamon-infused tomato sauce, fried onions, and lashings of garlic vinegar or lemon juice—is Egypt’s most popular comfort food. The cult place to eat it is Abou Tarek, a 61-year-old, two-story restaurant near Tahrir Square, whose neighborhood patrons include car mechanics, journalists, and the staff of several contemporary art galleries, who sit at communal tables while wide-screen TVs broadcast recitations from the Koran. The only other thing on the menu is a dessert of rice cooked in rosewater and milk (16 Maarouf-Shamplion St.).







## 
1. **[APERITIVO](http://labodegaegypt.com)** Cairo’s late-night dinner scene wilted after the revolution, with bon vivants choosing to stay home amid the resulting economic downturn and security vacuum. Inspired by the high design and bar cuisine of Milan, Aperitivo is one of the few upscale eateries in Cairo to thrive, thanks to a loyal—and, in many cases, activist—clientele. They enjoy small plates at the bar and delicate risottos, pastas, and grills served in a pre-1930s-themed setting. Architects, public relations executives, bankers, and filmmakers take meetings here just after 5 p.m., when the bar opens. The dinner crowd rolls in at 8:30 p.m. (157 26th July St., Zamalek; 20-2-735-0543).







## 
1. **PICNIC ON A NILE SAILBOAT** You supply the picnic (a hotel box lunch and minibar drinks will do), and the captains at Dok Dok Felucca will steer you on a felucca, an ancient type of lateen sailboat, still in common use. Dok Dok’s feluccas have cushioned benches surrounding a central table where you can lay out your feast. The going rate is about 50 Egyptian pounds ($8.50) per hour, plus a tip for the two crewmen, who tack between the Kasr Al Nil and University bridges and are used to clients—both Egyptians and non-Arabic-speaking expats—who bring a bottle of wine. The experience is best at sunset; boats operate from late morning until midnight (El Nil St., just across from the Four Seasons at Nile Plaza hotel; no phone).







## 
1. **CITADEL VIEW RESTAURANT, AL AZHAR PARK** Egyptian families, expats, and tourists book the terrace of this Fatamid-palace-styled restaurant, which serves well-prepared Egyptian salads, dips, grilled meats, and classic dishes such as pigeon soup and fattah, baked layers of rice, meat, bread, and a vinegar- and garlic-spiced yogurt. Fresh-squeezed fruit juices and hot-from-the oven pitas also make for a wonderful meal. The big draw is the spectacular terrace view of the Saladin Citadel and hundreds of surrounding Islamic monuments. Stay away on chilly evenings, as the alternative indoor space is dark and claustrophobic (Al Azhar Park, Salah Salem Rd.; 20-2-2510-9150/1; no alcohol served).











Image Courtesy of La Bodega Eygpt
